coredata.dc:title: The shape resonance for CO chemisorbed on Ni(110) studied by vibrational electron energy loss spectroscopy
coredata.dc:creator: Jones, T.S.
Ashton, M.R.
Ding, M.Q.
Richardson, N.V.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Vibrational high-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy has been used to identify the shape resonance for CO chemisorbed on Ni(110) at room temperature. The intensity of the CO stretching vibration is found to be enhanced at an incident electron energy E i = 18 eV. Angular-dependent measurements were recorded over a range of incident electron energies (E i = 9–35 eV). For E i = 18 eV, the intensity of the CO stretch is peaked dominantly along the surface normal. This correlates with enhanced resonance scattering along the CO internuclear bond axis. We compare the energy of the shape resonance with previous electron scattering studies of gas-phase and condensed layers of CO, and also with recent inverse photoemission studies of CO chemisorbed on Ni(100).

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETrERS 29 September 1989 Volume 161, number 6 THE SHAPE RESONANCE FOR CO CHEMISORBED ON Ni(11O) STUDIED BY VIBRATIONAL ELECTRON ENERGY LOSS SPECTROSCOPY T.S. JONES, M.R. ASHTON, M.Q. DING and N.Y. RICHARDSON Surface Science Research Centre, The University of Liverpool P.O. Box 147, Liverpool, L69 3BX. UK Received 8 June 1989; in final form 19 July 1989 Vibrational high-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy has been used to idenlify the shape resonance for CO chemisorbed on Ni( 110) at room temperature. The intensity of the CO stretching vibration is found to be enhanced at an incident electron energy E~ =18 eV. Angular-dependent measurements were recorded over a range of incident electron energies (E~ 9 35 eV). For E~= 18 eV, the intensity of the CO stretch is peaked dominantly along the surface normal. This correlates with enhanced resonance scattering along the C O internuclear bond axis. We compare the energy of the shape resonance with previous electron scattering studies of gas-phase and condensed layers of CO, and also with recent inverse photoemission studies of CO chemisorbed on Ni( 100). Vibrational mode enhancement, due to temporary negative ion formation, is a phenomenon which has been known for some time to dothinate inelastic electron scattering of gas-phase molecules [1 3]. Such a scattering mechanism, known generally as resonance scattering, involves capture of the inci- dent electron in a quasibound state of the molecule. Since the electron is generally captured in an orbital of antibonding character, the equilibrium internu- clear separation of the negative ion state is extended relative to that of the ground state molecule. Throughout the negative ion lifetime (typically r~ 10 ~ l0 ~ s), the nuclei separate towards a new equilibrium position. When the electron escapes, the nuclei are extended relative to the neutral equilib- rium separation and the molecule may be left in a vibrationally excited state. The overall result is an enhanced intensity of the fundamental vibrational modes, often accompanied by significant overtone intensity, over a relatively narrow incident electron energy range, E1. Recent vibrational high-resolution electron energy loss experiments (HREELS) of molecules adsorbed at surfaces have shown evidence for similar intensity enhancements, although such observations have been largely restricted to weakly bound physisorbed sys- tems and condensed layers [4 9]. Similar enhance- ments are now being reported for more strongly bound chemisorbed molecules, where the lifetime of the transient ion appears to be significantly reduced [10 l 6]. Recently, we reported a detailed study of a resonant enhancement in vibrational mode inten- sity (the symmetric O C O stretching vibration, v5( COO)), centred at E1 = 14 eV, for the surface for- mate species (HCOO) chemisorbed on Ni( 110) El 3 15]. The final state was identified as being sim- ilar to the shape resonances observed in near-edge X-ray absorption (NEXAFS) experiments of the surface HCOO species adsorbed on copper surfaces El 7,18] ~. Of particular importance in identifying a resonant state is the strong angular dependence ob- served in the inelastically scattered electron distri- bution [8,9,13 15,20,211. For HCOO/Ni( 110), the HREELS measurements revealed that at the reso- nance threshold (E1 = 14 cV), the electrons were dominantly scattered at high emission angles rela- tive to the surface nonnal, correlating with enhanced resonance scattering along the direction of the C O bonds of the adsorbed HCOO species El 3 15]. ~ Note that since there are Iwo C O bonds of the adsorbed HCOO species, there are in fact two shape resonances. These have recently been resolved in a NEXAFS study of HCOO/ Cu(llO)bySomersetal. [19]. 0009-2614/89/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers E.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 467 Volume 161, number6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEflERS 29 September 1989 In this Letter, we present evidence for a similar resonant enhancement of the C O stretching vibra- tion (v(CO)), centred at E1= 18 eV, for CO chem- isorbed on Ni (110). This resonant energy and the strong angular dependence in the intensity of the y (CO) mode, measured at E1 = 18 eV, allows the res- onant state to be identified as the molecular shape resonance which has been well documented in elec- tron scattering studies of gas-phase [22,23] and con- densed layers [7] of CO and also from valence level photoemission [24,25], NEXAFS [26] and inverse photoemission (IPES) [27] studies of chemisorbed CO. Experiments were carried out in an ultra high vac- uum (UHV) chamber (base pressure c2x 10 mbar) equipped with HREELS, low-energy electron diffraction (LEED) and mass spectrometer. The HREEL spectrometer (YSW Scientific Instruments Ltd.) consists of a fixed monochromator and a ro- tatable analyser, both of the 180 hemispherical de- flector type. HREEL spectra were recorded with in- cident electron energies E1, up to 35 eV and with a resolution of 8 meV full width half maximum (fwhm). The angular resolution of the spectrometer is t 2 (fwhm). Specular and off-specular spectra were recorded. The incident angle of the electrons (Of) was fixed at 71 and off-specular spectra were measured by rotation of the analyser. All angles quoted are with respect to the surface normal (fig. 1). The Ni( 110) crystal was cleaned by cycles of ar- gon ion sputtering (500 eV, sample ion current t 5 10 ~.tA, sample temperature t 500 K) and annealing (sample temperature t 1000 K) procedures. Sur- face cleanliness was monitored by the appearance of a sharp p (1 X 1) LEED pattern and the absence of any loss peaks in the tail of the elastic HREELS peak in the specular direction. The clean surface was ex- posedto tl8OL (1 L=l06Torrs)ofCOatasur- face temperature of 300 320 K. No ordered struc- tures were observed consistent with previous studies of CO adsorbed on Ni(llO) at 300 K 128]. Vibra- tional spectra, recorded in specular scattering geometry, showed evidence for both on-top (v(CO)=253 meV) and bridged (v(CO)=244 meV) site adsorption (fig. 1). No attempt was made to produce the ordered p2mg LEED structure, which forms at an ambient CO pressure of t 10_6 mbar for Fig. 1 The electron scattering geometry employed in measuring the electron energy loss spectrum for CO adsorbed on Ni( 110). All angles in the text (i.e. incident angle O~ and emission angle 0,) refer to the surface normal. Also illustrated are the two adsorp- tian sites of the CO molecule, having vibrational frequencies of 253 meV (on-top) and 244 meV (bridge) respectively. Fig. 2. The combined intensity of the CO stretching vibration, ~(oe), for bridge and on-top adsorption on Ni( 110), plotted as a function of incident electron energy E1. The electron scattering geometry was fixed such that the incident angle of the electrons, 9~=710, and the emission angle of the electrons, 0,=0 (all angles relative to the surface normal). room temperature adsorption, when CO occupies only short bridge adsorption sites and is believed to be tilted with respect to the surface normal [28]. All the intensity measurements shown here were eval- uated by integrating the total area of the CO vibra- tional peaks for both on-top and bridged site ad- sorption. Intensities are not normalised to specular elastic intensities. Fig. 2 shows the combined intensity of the CO E1 On fop CO Bridge CO <110> clOD> C L o 01000 CO/NIl 10) * * 10 15 20 25 30 35 Electron Energy (eV) 468 (6a) CO Binding energy (eV) CO(gasphase) 19.5 ~ CO (condensed) 19~ COJNi(11O) l8 ~ COJNi(100) l8 ~ Volume 161 number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEU ERS 29 September 1989 stretching vibration, p(CO), for both on-top and bridged site adsorption, for a range of incident elec- tron energies E,, and for off-specular scattering ge- ometry. The electron scattering geometry (fig. 1) was fixed such that 9~ = 710 and the emitted electrons were collected along the surface normal (i.e. O~=0 ). Since the angular resolution of the spectrometer is t 2 , it can be assumed that any intensity in Ip(~) due to long-range dipole scattering (which dominates spec- ular HREELS studies of adsorbed CC) is negligible. Clearly, ~(CO) passes through a substantial maxi- mum at E, = 18eV, and then decreases with increas- ing E,. We assign this increased intensity to a reso- nant enhancement process involving formation of a temporary negative ion. It should be noted that, un- like the situation for HCOO/Ni (110) [13 15], there is very little evidence for significant overtone inten- sity. This point will be addressed later in the paper. ~(cO) was also measured as a function of electron emission angle (Os), for a fixed O, = 71 and a range of fixed incident electron energies. Fig. 3 shows such an angular dependence for E, = 9, 18 and 35 eV. Clearly, at the resonance energy (18 eV) ~(CO) is significantly enhanced as O~-/0, i.e. for scattering along the direction of the surface normal. For elec- tron energies well away from the resonance thresh- old (i.e. E,= 9 and 35 eV in fig. 3), no such angular enhancement is observed. We identify the resonant state as the CO molecular shape resonance, in which the incident electron is trapped by a centrifugal barrier created by the mo- lecular potential, before tunneling out through the barrier and into the continuum [29]. A similar, very broad resonance, has been identified at 22 eV by Chutjian et al. [22] in electron scattering studies of gas phase CO. It was first assigned as arising from doubly excited states [22]. However, Tronc et al. 123], in a more detailed inelastic electron scattering study of gas phase CO, identified the state at 19.5 eV (width t 7 eV) as the shape resonance (table 1). The shape resonance, which is identified as the 2~ mo- lecular state, was noted to be considerably weaker than the lower energy (2.25 eV) 2fl resonance. This was reflected in a substantial decrease in the cross- section for overtone losses [231. More recently, the shape resonance has also been observed at 19 eV for films of CO condensed onto a platinum substrate [71 and at 18 eV, serving as an initial state in IPES mea- surements of CO chemisorbed on Ni (100) [27]. Again, in the case of condensed films of CO, a sub- stantial decrease in the intensity of higher vibra- tional losses was observed compared with the lower energy 2f[ resonance [7]. Table 1 The binding energies of the CO molecular shape resonance ac- cessed by capture of an incident electron in a quasibound orbital of the molecule, i.e. (6a) . The energies are taken from inelastic electron scattering studies of gas phase CO (23], for muftilayers of CO condensed onto a platinum substrate [71 and our HREELS study of CO chemisorbed on Ni (110). The value for CO chenu- sorbed on Ni (100) is taken from a recent inverse photoemission study (IPES), in which the shape resonance is accessed as an ini- tial state [27]. All energies are referenced to the vacuum level. In order to achieve this common reference level, a work function of 6 eV is assumed for the IPES measurements. The superscripts refer to references in the text CO/Ni(1l0) o Ej=9eV E1=l8eV 4c00 3mo 10m C D o o o o C a C O o * . E~35eV (5cos3O-3cose)2 o D 10 20 30 40 Emission Angle (es) Fig. 3. The intensity of the CO stretching vibration, y(oe), for bridge and on-top adsorption on Ni (110), plotted as a function of electron emission angle, 8,, for three different incident elec- tron energies, E,=9, 18 and 35eV. For all of the measurements, the incident angle of the electrons was fixed at 71 0, The solid line represents a (5 cos30 3 cos g)2 fit to ~ recorded at E1= 18 eV. ~ Ref. [23]. ~ Ref. [7]. C) This work. il) Ref. [271. 469 Volume 161, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEUERS 29 September 1989 From table 1, it can be seen that the shape reso- nance lies approximately l 2 eV lower in binding energy (all values referenced to the vacuum level) in the adsorbed examples compared with gas phase CO (note that for chemisorption, a work function of 6 eV is assumed [27,28]). This shift, due to screening effects of the substrate, is a consequence of the re- duction in potential energy of the negative ion as a result of an interaction between the ion and its image in the metal [4]. Multiple scattering effects in the outgoing wave may also cause a shift in the reso- nance energy [30], although Gerber and Herzenberg L 31] suggest that the shift is small and the greater effect of multiple scattering is tQ admix partial waves of lower angular momentum values (l-values) into the resonance. Since it is well known that, at these coverages, CO is bound to the surface with its internuclear axis aligned along the surface normal, the angular mea- surements plotted in fig. 3 show that, at the reso- nance energy of 18 eV, the scattering is dominantly directed along the C O bond axis. This result is in strong agreement with the observed angular depen- dence in the resonance scattering for v,(CQ ~) for the surface HCOO species adsorbed on Ni( 110) [13 151. In a molecular orbital description of CO, the quasibound state (6a) derives from an antibonding interaction between C- and 0-based 2p~ atomic or- bitaIs directed along the C O internuclear bond axis (the z-axis). Expansion in terms of spherical har- monics, centred on the z-axis and between the two nuclei, is then dominated by the 3, 0> term. The electron density associated with the resonance is therefore likely to be dominated by a function of the form (Scos3O 3cosu)2. In the region O_300 away from the z-axis, the observed behaviour is less sharply peaked about the surface normal (fig. 3). Vibra- tional motion can be responsible for tilting the C 0 axis relative to the surface normal. Electron-stimu- lated desorption experiments (ESDIAD) of ad- sorbed CO indicate a half-angle at half-maximum of the ion cones of approximately 160 at room tem- perature [321. This, however, is insufficient to ex- plain the broadening shown in fig. 3 [33]. An al- ternative explanation is that lower 1-value spherical harmonic components are involved in the resonant state. In a gas-phase homonuclear diatomic mole- cule, symmetry arguments permit the admixture of the 1, 0> component. For a heteronuclear diatomic molecule and for chemisorption on a surface, even 1-values (tO, 0>, 12, 0>) can also participate. This is our favoured interpretation of the broadened an- gular distribution observed in fig. 3. The angular properties of electrons scattering from such a shape resonance have been well documented in a number of angle-resolved valence level pho- toemission studies of CO adsorbed on a variety of transition metals [24,25]. In certain cases, such studies have been used to infer the orientation of the CO molecule at the surface [251. lt appears that a similar angular dependence in the scattering from shape resonances is being observed in our HREELS studies of adsorbed molecules containing C-O bonds. However, for detailed information to be gained, a full multiple scattering theory calculation, incorpo- rating the effects of the substrate, must be attempted. Such calculations have being carried out by Rous et al. [34] for a negative ion resonance, observed at = 9 eV for 0~ physisorbed on graphite, in which a strong angular dependence in the inelastically scat- tered electrons has been reported [8,9]. Finally, it is worth commenting on the lack of any significant overtone intensity, at the resonance en- ergy, in the case of adsorbed CO. It is well known from gas-phase electron scattering studies, that one of the major signatures of a resonant process is an enhancement in the intensity of not only fundamen- tal vibrational modes but also a number of overtones [l 3]. Using a harmonic oscillator model, Gadzuk [35,36] has shown that the ratio of the fundamental to overtone intensity is a measure of the lifetime of the negative ion state. For weakly bound physisorbed systems (e.g. N2/Ag [4 J), the number of overtones observed is considerably reduced on comparison with the gas-phase species. It has been calculated by Gad- zuk [35] that the lifetime of the resonant state in the physisorbed N2 is t 40% that of gas-phase N2. For the more strongly bound chemisorbed system, the lifetime of the negative ion is expected to be even shorter because of the new decay channels provided by the surface. Since for CO/Ni (110), there is very little evidence for any significant overtone intensity in the HREELS experiment, the implication is that the relatively high-energy shape resonance (18 eV) has a very short lifetime. For HCOO chemisorption, two overtone losses were clearly observed [13 15], 470 Volume 161, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 29 September 1989 possibly indicating that the lifetime of the lower en- ergy shape resonance (14 eV) is slightly longer. In- deed, as already mentioned, even for gas-phase and condensed films of CO, the shape resonance is weak compared with the lower energy 2fl resonance [7,23]. A second possibility for the low resonant intensity for adsorbed CO derives from an experimental prob- lem. We have shown that the shape resonance is most strongly accessed by electrons scattering along the C O bond of the molecule, i.e. for electrons directed in and out along the bond axis. For the surface HCOO species, the bonding geometry is ideally suited for resonant enhancement when the electrons are inci- dent and scattered at relatively large angles relative to the surface normal [13 J. For adsorbed CO, ideal scattering is for electrons incident and emitted along the surface normal, a scattering geometry which is inaccessible with our current spectrometer design (where a minimum between incident and scattered beams of 70 must be maintained). In conclusion, vibrational HREELS has been used to identify the shape resonance for CO chemisorbed on Ni (110). The intensity of the CO stretching vi- bration is enhanced at E1 =18 eV and the scattering is dominated by electrons emitted along the direc- tion of the C O bond. The energy of the resonant state compares favourably with electron scattering studies of gas-phase CO [23] and condensed layers of CO [7], with a l 2 eV decrease in binding energy compared with the gas-phase value being observed due to image potential effects. The shape resonance is found to have the same energy as that accessed as an initial state in a recent inverse photoemission study of CO/Ni( 100) [27]. The lack of significant overtone intensity in the HREELS measurements is most probably due to a particularly short lifetime for the relatively high energy shape resonance and also an unfavourable electron scattering geometry. Chem. 39 (1988) 395. 472 onclusion, vibrational HREELS has been used to identify the shape resonance for CO chemisorbed on Ni (110). The intensity of the CO stretching vi- bration is enhanced at E1 =18 eV and the scattering is dominated by electrons emitted along the direc- tion of the C O bond. The energy of the resonant state compares favourably with electron scattering studies of gas-phase CO [23] and condensed layers of CO [7], with a l 2 eV decrease in binding energy compared with the gas-phase value being observed due to image potential effects. The shape resonance is found to have the same energy as that accessed as an initial state in a recent inverse photoemission study of CO/Ni( 100) [27]. The lack of significant overtone intensity in the HREELS measurements is most probably due to a particularly short lifetime for the relatively high energy shape resonance and also an unfavourable electron scattering geometry. head.ce:title: The shape resonance for CO chemisorbed on Ni(110) studied by vibrational electron energy loss spectroscopy

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Surface Science Research Centre, The University of Liverpool P.O. Box 147, Liverpool, L69 3BX, UK

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Vibrational high-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy has been used to identify the shape resonance for CO chemisorbed on Ni(110) at room temperature. The intensity of the CO stretching vibration is found to be enhanced at an incident electron energy E i = 18 eV. Angular-dependent measurements were recorded over a range of incident electron energies (E i = 9–35 eV). For E i = 18 eV, the intensity of the CO stretch is peaked dominantly along the surface normal. This correlates with enhanced resonance scattering along the CO internuclear bond axis. We compare the energy of the shape resonance with previous electron scattering studies of gas-phase and condensed layers of CO, and also with recent inverse photoemission studies of CO chemisorbed on Ni(100).

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: J. Somers, A.W. Robinson, Th. Lindner, D. Ricken and A.M. Bradshaw, Phys. Rev. B, in press
T.S. Jones and N.V. Richardson, to be published
